title: Hockney’s ‘Sur la Terrasse’ Could Net $45 Million at Christie’s
text:
Text size

David Hockney’s Sur la Terrasse, which represents his last depiction of his lover and greatest muse, Peter Schlesinger, could realize $25 million to $45 million at a Christie’s New York auction in November.

The painting has been in an anonymous, private collection, and has never appeared at auction in over 46 years, Christie’s said. The auction house will feature the painting at its evening sale of post-war and contemporary art on Nov. 13.

Hockney, 82, began painting Sur la Terrasse (meaning “on the terrace”)in March 1971, and completed it that summer during a time he and Schlesinger’s relationship declined. The two met in 1966 while Hockney was teaching at the University of California at Los Angeles, where Schlesinger, now 71, was an art student and model.

The canvas was based on a series of photographs taken on the balcony of the couple’s room at the Hôtel de la Mamounia in Marrakesh, Morocco, where they had spent two weeks in Feb. 1971, according to Christie’s.

“This work marks a momentous turning point in the artist’s personal and professional lives,” Ana Maria Celis, head of evening sale of post-war and contemporary art at Christie’s, said in a statement. “The tenderness and nostalgia of this moment is unmistakable in Schlesinger’s position with his back facing the artist, as he looks into the wilds that lie beyond their hotel terrace in Marrakesh.”

By casting himself as a voyeur, Hockney was bidding a private farewell to his lover. The sense of estrangement was revisited in his iconic 1972 work, Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures), which also depicts Schlesinger.

Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures) sold for $90 million at Christie’s New York in November 2018, marking the most expensive work for a living artist and breaking the previous record set by the 2013 sale of Jeff Koons ’ Balloon Dog (Orange) for $58.4 million. The honor was reclaimed by Koons in May 2019, when his Rabbit sold for more than $91 million at Christie’s in New York.

Sur la Terrasse will be on view at Christie’s Los Angeles galleries starting Oct. 15.
